channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: German Law Requires More Women on Corporate Boards
item.description: The law requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, left, and the German minister of family affairs, Manuela Schwesig, at a session of Parliament in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: South Sudan Peace Talks Stall
item.description: The Ethiopian prime minister, Hailemariam Desalegn, said in a statement that he regretted that “the talks did not produce the necessary breakthrough.”
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Companies Turn Tables on Human Rights Lawyers
item.description: American companies accused of human rights abuses abroad are on the counterattack, seeking to bring down the lawyers who targeted them.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: BARRY MEIER
item.media:credit: Diego M. Radzinschi/The National Law Journal
item.media:description: Terrence Collingsworth is one of a band of lawyers who have targeted multinational corporations for mistreating workers abroad. Now they find themselves on the defensive.

item.title: China Blocks Web Access to Documentary on Nation’s Air Pollution
item.description: “Under the Dome” had hundreds of millions of views on Chinese websites in the past week within days of its release, more than any other video in recent years.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Residential buildings amid heavy air pollution in Wuhan in Hubei Province on Feb. 16.

item.title: Indians Find Ways to See Rape Documentary Despite Ban
item.description: The Indian government tried to suppress a BBC documentary about a 2012 gang rape, but those efforts only increased interest in the film.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Mukesh Singh, convicted of rape and murder, awaits execution on India's death row. Mr. Singh was interviewed about the crime in a BBC documentary, which the Indian government has tried to suppress.

item.title: ISIS Bulldozing of Ancient Nimrud Site in Iraq Stirs Outrage
item.description: Archaeologists despaired that the Islamic State aimed to systematically destroy the relics of a birthplace of civilization.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A relief of a lamassu, a mythological creature with the body of a lion, wings and a bearded human head, in the Palace of Ashurnasirpal II in Nimrud, Iraq.

item.title: Putin Announces a Pay Cut for Himself and Kremlin Officials
item.description: With ordinary Russians grumbling about the sharp rise in food prices, the president announced that he and other officials will take a 10 percent cut in pay.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Briton Arrested Over Cyberattack on U.S. Defense Department
item.description: Data was stolen in June from a messaging service used by the department’s employees, including email addresses and phone numbers for about 800 contacts.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Indian Mob Seizes Prisoner Accused of Rape and Beats Him to Death
item.description: A crowd of thousands overcame armed police officers and seized the man, accused of raping a woman from a tribal community.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Parliamentary Panel Urges Britain to Stand Up for Hong Kong
item.description: A committee warned that Hong Kong’s high degree of autonomy was at risk and called on London to take a stronger stand on behalf of democratic change in its former colony.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Pro-democracy marchers in Hong Kong displaying British colonial flags last month in the first major rally since the police cleared protesters from the streets in December.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Year After Flight 370’s Disappearance, Grief and Anger Endure
item.description: Families of the Chinese passengers on Flight 370 described the pain of holidays without their loved ones, their frustration at the lack of answers and their anger over their treatment by the Malaysian authorities and the airline.
item.dc:creator: MIA LI
item.media:description: Chinese police officers trying to block reporters from interviewing relatives of passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in Beijing on Jan. 30. Many of the relatives demanded that Malaysian officials retract their statement that all on board died, saying they refused to believe this without hard evidence.

item.title: Memo From Moscow: With Nemtsov’s Killing, a Leadership Void Widens for Russia’s Opposition
item.description: The killing of Boris Y. Nemtsov leaves Russia’s critics at a crossroads over whether and how they take a role in the nation’s political life.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A portrait of Boris Y. Nemtsov at the Andrei Sakharov Center in Moscow on Sunday, where a memorial service was held.

item.title: South Korea Says Attacker of U.S. Ambassador, Mark Lippert, Acted Alone
item.description: The South Korean police said on Friday that they were seeking to bring attempted murder and other criminal charges against an anti-American activist who slashed the United States ambassador to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The American envoy to South Korea, Mr. Lippert, left a Seoul cultural center after being slashed on his face and arm.

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Theft at Spy Headquarters
item.description: The theft of water faucets from the new headquarters of Germany’s foreign intelligence service, under construction in Berlin, caused leaks and water damage, the police said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan and China to Hold Security Talks
item.description: Japanese and Chinese officials will hold their first security talks in four years in Tokyo this month.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Senate Will Postpone Debate on Iran
item.description: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, will postpone consideration of a bill giving Congress the authority to review any deal President Obama reaches with Iran on its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Gunmen Kill a Navy Officer
item.description: A navy officer put in charge of Mexico’s second-largest port in an effort to wrest control of it from a drug gang was shot and killed in what the authorities said Thursday was a robbery attempt.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: World Briefing: Singapore: Caning and Jail for Vandals
item.description: Singapore on Thursday sentenced two German men to three strokes of a rattan cane and nine months in prison after they were found guilty of vandalizing a public train carriage, according to court documents.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ISIS Is Adept on Twitter, Study Finds
item.description: While Twitter has suspended many users linked to the Islamic State, a study says at least 46,000 accounts publicize the group’s message of death.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and VINDU GOEL

item.title: Iran Gains Influence in Iraq as Shiite Forces Fight ISIS
item.description: Iran’s powerful influence in Iraq has been on display as the fight against the Islamic State militants around Tikrit has unfolded, with strong support for Shiite leaders where they were once feared.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
